oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p>The Tetraodontidae family encompasses several species which attract scientific interest in terms of their ecology and evolution. The silver-cheeked toadfish (<jats:italic>Lagocephalus sceleratus</jats:italic>) is a well-known “invasive sprinter” that has invaded and spread, in less than a decade, throughout the Eastern and part of the Western Mediterranean Sea from the Red Sea through the Suez Canal. In this study, we built and analysed the first near-chromosome level genome assembly of <jats:italic>L. sceleratus</jats:italic> and explored its evolutionary landscape. Through a phylogenomic analysis, we positioned <jats:italic>L. sceleratus</jats:italic> closer to <jats:italic>T. nigroviridis,</jats:italic> compared to other members of the family, while gene family evolution analysis revealed that genes associated with the immune response have experienced rapid expansion, providing a genetic basis for studying how <jats:italic>L. sceleratus</jats:italic> is able to achieve highly successful colonisation. Moreover, we found that voltage-gated sodium channel (NaV 1.4) mutations previously connected to tetrodotoxin resistance in other pufferfishes are not found in <jats:italic>L. sceleratus</jats:italic>, highlighting the complex evolution of this trait. The high-quality genome assembly built here is expected to set the ground for future studies on the species biology.</jats:p>
